title: Swithland Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: Kate Jewell / Swithland Reservoir
images.caption: Looking SE from the dam. The bank in the view is all in SK5614. The reservoir is the most reliable place in the county to see Peregrines in the winter and the best time is a calm evening such as in this picture.

images.title: Mat Fascione / Swithland Reservoir
images.caption: A view of Kinchley Lane running along the north western edge of the reservoir.

images.title: Mat Fascione / Bridge at Swithland Reservoir
images.caption: Bridge at Swithland Reservoir. Built in 1896 this bridge carries Kinchley Lane across the weir at the northern end of lake.

images.title: Mat Fascione / Viaduct over Swithland Reservoir
images.caption: Viaduct which carries the Great Central Railway over the reservoir.

images.title: Andy Bryant / Pump house at the top of Swithland Reservoir
images.caption: Victorian pump house at the Northern end of the reservoir, also known to Geocachers as Dumbledore's Retreat.

images.title: Kate Jewell / Countryside at Swithland Wood
images.caption: Countryside at Swithland Wood Looking towards Cropston. The reservoir SK5411 is behind the trees in the centre of the picture. The wall is made of local Mountsorrel granite.

images.title: Mat Fascione / The Griffin Inn, Swithland
images.caption: The Griffin Inn, Swithland. This country pub is a fine choice for some post walk refreshments.

images.title: Ashley Dace / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: The Montsorrel Railway which runs past the lake.

description: This pretty reservoir is located just to the south east of Loughborough. The Leicestershire Round long distance trail runs along the north eastern side of the water. You can follow the trail from the nearby village of Woodhouse Eaves to the water. It's about a one mile walk through farmland to the Aqueduct and Boat House at the reservoir's northern tip. It's a very pretty spot with nice views across the water to the surrounding woodland and countryside. Also look out for the steam trains of the Great Central Railway passing over Swithland Viaduct. The reservoir is popular with bird watchers with lots of water loving visitors to look out for. Keep your eyes peeled for Great Crested Grebe and Mandarin Ducks on the water. Above the lake you can look out for Peregrines in the winter months. To extend your walk you can explore Charnwood Forest on our circular walk and visit the nearby Bradgate Country Park and Beacon Hill Country Park. These two lovely parks are located very close to start point for this route at Woodhouse Eaves. They both have good walking trails with climbs to great viewpoints which provide extensive views over this pretty area.
